7 Days

7 Days in the Yucatán Peninsula

From Caribbean Beaches to Ancient Pyramids

The Yucatán Peninsula offers Mexico's most iconic combination: pristine Caribbean beaches, ancient Mayan pyramids, mysterious cenotes, and colorful colonial towns. This 7-day itinerary takes you from the resort beaches of Cancún through bohemian Tulum, historic Valladolid, and the wonder of Chichén Itzá—hitting every highlight while maintaining a relaxed pace.

Trip Highlights

  • Snorkel in crystal-clear Caribbean waters
  • Explore the cliff-top ruins of Tulum
  • Swim in ancient cenotes
  • Witness Chichén Itzá at sunrise
  • Wander colonial Valladolid streets
  • Taste authentic Yucatecan cuisine
Duration
7 Days
Best Time
November to April for best weather; avoid Spring Break (March) for fewer crowds
Budget (Mid-Range)
$1,500-2,500 USD per person

Day-by-Day Itinerary

1

Arrive in Cancún

Cancún Hotel Zone

Arrive at Cancún International Airport (CUN) and transfer to your hotel in the Hotel Zone. Spend the afternoon recovering from travel on Playa Delfines, one of Cancún's most beautiful public beaches with the iconic Cancún sign. Watch the sunset over the lagoon from your hotel.

Today's Activities:
  • Airport transfer and hotel check-in
  • Relax at Playa Delfines
  • Sunset dinner at Puerto Madero or Lorenzillo's
2

Cancún Beaches & Isla Mujeres

Cancún / Isla Mujeres

Take the morning ferry to Isla Mujeres (30 minutes from Puerto Juárez). Rent a golf cart to explore this charming island, swim at Playa Norte (consistently rated Mexico's best beach), snorkel at the underwater sculpture museum MUSA, and enjoy fresh ceviche with ocean views.

Today's Activities:
  • Ferry to Isla Mujeres (8am recommended)
  • Golf cart island tour
  • Playa Norte beach time
  • MUSA snorkeling or glass-bottom boat
  • Lunch at Playa Lancheros
3

Transfer to Tulum via Cenotes

Tulum

Drive south to Tulum (2 hours), stopping at the Ruta de los Cenotes near Puerto Morelos. Swim in magical underground cenotes like Cenote Azul or Kin Ha. Arrive in Tulum mid-afternoon and explore the beach zone with its famous bohemian beach clubs and jungle boutique hotels.

Today's Activities:
  • Check out of Cancún hotel
  • Drive Ruta de los Cenotes (2-3 cenotes)
  • Lunch in Puerto Morelos
  • Arrive Tulum, settle in
  • Sunset at a beach club
4

Tulum Ruins & Beach Day

Tulum

Start early at the Tulum Archaeological Site before crowds arrive (opens 8am). The cliff-top ruins with Caribbean views are Mexico's most photographed. Descend to the beach below for a swim, then spend the afternoon at a beach club like Ahau or Papaya Playa. Evening is for the famous Tulum dining scene.

Today's Activities:
  • Tulum ruins at 8am opening
  • Beach below the ruins
  • Lunch at Hartwood (reservations essential)
  • Beach club afternoon
  • Dinner at Arca or Gitano
5

Gran Cenote & Transfer to Valladolid

Valladolid

Visit Gran Cenote early morning when light beams stream through the cave ceiling (best 9-10am). After swimming with turtles, drive to the Pueblo Mágico of Valladolid (1.5 hours). Explore the colorful colonial centro, swim at Cenote Zací in the middle of town, and dine on Yucatecan specialties.

Today's Activities:
  • Gran Cenote sunrise visit
  • Drive to Valladolid
  • Lunch at Yerbabuena del Sisal
  • Cenote Zací swimming
  • Colonial centro walking tour
  • Dinner at El Mesón del Marqués
6

Chichén Itzá & Return to Cancún

Cancún

Depart at 6am for Chichén Itzá (45 minutes) to arrive at 8am opening before tour buses. Spend 2-3 hours exploring the pyramid of Kukulcán, the Ball Court, and the Temple of Warriors. Return toward Cancún, stopping at Cenote Ik Kil for a swim. Final evening in Cancún for shopping or nightlife.

Today's Activities:
  • Early departure for Chichén Itzá
  • Explore the archaeological site (2-3 hours)
  • Swim at Cenote Ik Kil
  • Return drive to Cancún
  • Final dinner and nightlife
7

Departure Day

Cancún

Depending on your flight time, enjoy a final morning at the beach, last-minute shopping at La Isla Shopping Village, or brunch at one of Cancún's excellent restaurants. Transfer to Cancún International Airport for your departure.

Today's Activities:
  • Final beach time or shopping
  • Airport transfer
  • Departure

Practical Information

Getting There

Fly into Cancún International Airport (CUN), Mexico's busiest. Direct flights from most major US and Canadian cities, plus European connections. Airport is 20 minutes from Hotel Zone.

Getting Around

Rent a car for maximum flexibility ($30-50/day). ADO buses connect major towns cheaply but slowly. Taxis and private transfers are available but expensive. Colectivos (shared vans) are cheap for coastal routes.

Frequently Asked Questions

Is 7 days enough for the Yucatán?

Yes, 7 days is perfect for the main highlights: beaches, Tulum, a colonial town, and Chichén Itzá. For deeper exploration including Mérida, Uxmal, or Holbox, consider 10-14 days.

Should I rent a car?

Highly recommended. A rental car ($30-50/day) gives you freedom to visit cenotes, leave early for ruins, and explore at your pace. Without a car, you'll rely on expensive tours or slow public buses.

Is the Yucatán safe?

The Yucatán Peninsula is one of Mexico's safest regions. Tourism is the main industry, and the area is well-policed. Use normal precautions (secure valuables, avoid isolated areas at night).

What's the best time to visit?

November to April is dry season with warm weather and low humidity. Avoid Spring Break (March) for fewer crowds. Summer is hot and humid with afternoon rain but fewer tourists and lower prices.
